revision.text:
{{merge|6.5×54mm_Mannlicher–Schönauer|discuss=Talk:6.5×53mmR#Merger proposal|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox Firearm Cartridge |name= 6.5×53mmR |image= [[File:6.5x53 Mannlicher.jpg|300px]] |caption= Military cartridge |origin= {{flagicon|Austria-Hungary}} [[Austria-Hungary]] |type= [[Rifle|Military rifle cartridge]] |service= 1893-1945 |used_by=[[Netherlands]]
[[Romania]]
[[Kingdom of Portugal]]{{cite book|author=Philip Peterson|title=Standard Catalog of Military Firearms: The Collector's Price and Reference Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pno1p5I7FEUC&pg=PA283|date=20 July 2011|publisher=Gun Digest Books|isbn=1-4402-1451-4|page=283}} |wars= [[Aceh War]]
[[World War I]]
[[World War II]] |designer= |design_date= 1892 |manufacturer= |production_date= |number= |variants= |is_SI_specs=yes |parent= |case_type=[[Rim (firearms)|Rimmed]], bottleneck{{cite book |last=Johnson |first=Melvin M., Jr. |authorlink =Melvin Johnson |title =Rifles and Machine Guns |publisher =William Morrow & Company |volume = |edition = |date =1944 |location =New York |pages =384 |isbn =}} |bullet=6.65 |neck=7.55 |shoulder=10.75 |base=11.48 |rim_dia=13.4 |rim_thick=1.25 |case_length=53 |length= |case_capacity= |rifling= |primer= |max_pressure= |max_cup= |filling= |filling_weight= |detonation= |yield= |is_SI_ballistics= |bwunit=grain |bw1=159 |btype1=RN |vel1=2433 |en1=2050 |bw2= |btype2= |vel2= |en2= |bw3= |btype3= |vel3= |en3= |bw4= |btype4= |vel4= |en4= |bw5= |btype5= |vel5= |en5= |test_barrel_length= |balsrc= ''Rifles and Machine Guns''
''.256 Mannlicher / 6.5x53R Reloading Data''{{cite web |url=http://www.loaddata.com/members/search_detail.cfm?MetallicID=1078 |title=.256 Mannlicher / 6.5x53R Reloading Data |last= |first= |website=Load Data |publisher= |accessdate=29 November 2013 }} }} The '''6.5×53mmR''' or '''.256 Mannlicher''' is a late 19th-century rimmed [[centerfire]] military rifle [[Cartridge (firearms)|cartridge]] similar to other early [[smokeless powder]] designs. It was the first of a series of {{convert|6.5|mm|in|sing=on}} [[Steyr Mannlicher|Mannlicher]] cartridges{{cite web |url=http://www.mannlicher.org/aboutmannlichers |title=A Mannlicher Introduction |last= |first= |website=Mannlicher Collectors Association |publisher= |accessdate=29 November 2013 }} and became the standard [[Romania]]n [[service rifle]] cartridge from 1893 to 1938,{{cite web |url=http://www.carbinesforcollectors.com/romania1.html |title=The Rifles of Romania 1878-1948 |last=Reynolds |first=Dan |website=Carbines for Collectors |publisher= |accessdate=29 November 2013 }} and the standard [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[Dutch Mannlicher|service rifle]] cartridge from 1895 to 1945.{{cite web |url=http://milpas.cc/rifles/ZFiles/Rifles%20of/Rifles%20of%20The%20East%20Asia%20Co.htm |title=Reissued Rifles of "The East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere" |last=Reynolds |first=Dan |website= |publisher= |accessdate=29 November 2013 }} ==Gallery== File:Dutch Mannlicher en-bloc clip.jpg|Empty [[Dutch Mannlicher]] [[en-bloc clip]] File:1911 Britannica - Cartridges.png|Comparison of [[.303 British]] with .256 Mannlicher ==See also== * [[Table of handgun and rifle cartridges]] ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:6.5x53mmR}} [[Category:Pistol and rifle cartridges]] [[Category:Military cartridges]]
